docs.lead_paragraph: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites ABIGAIL ADAMS SMITH MUSEUM, 421 East 61st Street, Manhattan. The structure, built in 1799 as the carriage house for the estate of Abigail Adams and Col. William Smith, was also the Mount Vernon Hotel from 1826 to 1833. The current exhibition, ''Smith's Folly: 200 Years of History, 60 Years of Preservation,'' includes a reproduction of a period carriage, photographs and articles related to the museum's history. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 A.M. to 4 P.M.; closed Mondays. Museum admission: $3; students and the elderly, $2; 12 and under, free. Information: (212) 838-6878.

docs.lead_paragraph: The head of a Federal advisory commission, an influential Republican, said today that Congress should increase Medicare payments for certain nursing home and hospital services because budget cuts appeared to be harming the quality of care for some patients. The statement, by Gail R. Wilensky, chairwoman of the Medicare Payment Advisory Commission, was a breakthrough for health care providers, who have been pleading with Congress to restore some of the money cut by the 1997 budget law.

headline.main: Chief of Panel Seeks Increase For Medicare

docs.abstract: Gail R Wilensky, head of Medicare Payment Advisory Commission, says that Congress should increase Medicare payments for certain nursing home and hospital services because budget cuts appear to be harming quality of care for some patients; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Five weeks after a mentally ill man randomly pushed him in front of an oncoming subway train that severed his legs, Edgar Rivera said yesterday that he harbored no anger toward his attacker and had no desire for revenge. Speaking for the first time since the April 28 incident, Mr. Rivera said he had only pity for the man, Julio Perez, 43, who witnesses have said shoved Mr. Rivera in front on an uptown No. 6 train at the 51st Street station in midtown. Mr. Perez, who has told investigators he has a history of mental illness and lived in a men's shelter for the mentally ill in upper Manhattan, remains in police custody and has been charged with attempted murder.

headline.main: Subway Victim Says He Harbors No Anger

docs.abstract: Edgar Rivera, five weeks after mentally ill man randomly pushed him in front of oncoming subway train that severed his legs, says that he harbors no anger toward his attacker, Julio Perez, and has no desire for revenge; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE latest browsers understand it, undergraduates are signing up for classes to learn it, and -- ultimate cyberspace compliment -- start-ups are forming around it. This Internet phenomenon of the moment is XML, or Extensible Markup Language, a new language that may one day power the second generation of the World Wide Web.

headline.main: A New Language May Ease Web Use

docs.abstract: Extensible Markup Language, or EXL, is new language that may one day power second generation of World Wide Web; Tim Bray, one of architects of new language, says XML is designed to fix Web's two main problems: it is slow and it is hard to find one piece of information needed during search; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Averting a strike that would have disrupted the Big Three auto makers, the teamsters' union and trucking companies that haul new cars to dealers reached a tentative contract agreement yesterday in negotiations that were the first big test for James P. Hoffa, the union's new president. Mr. Hoffa trumpeted the four-year contract as a major triumph for 12,800 car-haul workers, increasing their pay and pensions and providing health insurance to those who retire before the age of 65. In addition, the agreement for the first time provides coverage of prescription drugs, supplementing Medicare, for retirees 65 and over.

headline.main: Teamsters Reach an Accord With Haulers of New Cars

docs.lead_paragraph: Every week, it seems, brings a new food scare. And each scare, whether valid or dead wrong, has the potential to jolt the nation's diet. But ever since apple sales plummeted a decade ago, after a report by CBS News demonized the chemical Alar, food producers, crying foul, have been fighting back.

headline.main: Farmers' Right to Sue Grows, Raising Debate on Food Safety

docs.abstract: Critics say state laws intended to protect farmers and food companies from criticism that might scare consumers away their products are putting a chill on continuing debate about what the public should eat; though some publishers and broadcasters continue putting out reports on food, others have stricken information from scripts, avoided certain food issues or dropped book project out of concern over high cost of defending lawsuits; only 13 state such laws, but because books and television shows must play to a national audience, the statutes in effect are reaching across state borders, causing consumers everywhere to get less information about food safety; photo; map (M)
